description:
This adds an airspeed velocity configuration file.

Airspeed velocity (asv) is a benchmarking suite which can be run as part of a
continuous integration suite.  The idea is to develop a set of benchmarks and
then evaluate what the performance impact changes have.  Currently, my
"mercurial" branch of asv is required to run this.  Docs for asv:
http://spacetelescope.github.io/asv/ .

Note that the way ASV works is that the repository being tested is not really
the one you're living in -- it will make a new clone of the repo under "env".
This setup allows us to keep the main config for asv here in the repo, but to
test any version.

All benchmarks live under "benchmarks"; right now they are the examples.  I
have some I want to wrap in, as I am sure others will too.  The utility of the
tool will depend on the quality of benchmarks we can get in there -- and we
should aim for benchmarks that run on big data, not just small.

I'm optimistic this will be good for us going forward, and grateful that
such a cool tool has been made available by Space Telescope and Mike
Droettboom!
title: Add airspeed velocity config file

content.raw: I'd use anonymous access via *https* here. This will possibly be used by services that don't have ssh keys configured
content.html: I'd use anonymous access via https here. This will possibly be used by services that don't have ssh keys configured

content.html: Can you provide a link to those docs here?

content.raw:
Can you add some examples that benchmark some actual yt functions?

Can you add some more details somewhere on what your vision is for this?  Will this work like the automated testing?  If so, who will run it?  Maybe this deserves a YTEP.
content.html:
Can you add some examples that benchmark some actual yt functions?

Can you add some more details somewhere on what your vision is for this? Will this work like the automated testing? If so, who will run it? Maybe this deserves a YTEP.

content.raw:
Mike's presentation about asv from scipy 2014 might be worth looking at if you're curious about what it is:

http://youtube.com/watch?v=OsxJ5O6h8s0
content.html:

content.raw:
Great points, all of them.  I should have marked this with WIP; I only committed the template benchmarks that come with ASV, so they don't even test yt.  (And the comments in them are what come with the asv stuff, so they are unhelpful in the extreme.)  I think you're right, either a new YTEP or an update to the infrastructure YTEP is in order.

Basically, my vision is that right now we do not have a nice, detailed, automated way of saying "Things are getting faster" or "Things are getting slower."  What this does is use an existing framework that can test speed for given things against differing values for dependencies (i.e., numpy version, h5py version, sympy version), changeset hashes in the main repository, *and* machine.  And once the benchmarks are run, they get published and we can view them nicely.  They even come up with things like interactive visualization of where time is spent.

So what I want to see is added onto Fido reports for passing tests, is fido information about impact on performance.  This way we can keep track of it before things get accepted.  And, the act of writing a benchmark is an awful lot like writing a test, so we may even be able to re-use some code.  Since in the next little while I want to spend some time on performance, I thought this would be a nice way to make it systematic.

I'll start by porting the performance tests @samskillman and I worked on to it.
content.html:
Great points, all of them. I should have marked this with WIP; I only committed the template benchmarks that come with ASV, so they don't even test yt. (And the comments in them are what come with the asv stuff, so they are unhelpful in the extreme.) I think you're right, either a new YTEP or an update to the infrastructure YTEP is in order.

Basically, my vision is that right now we do not have a nice, detailed, automated way of saying "Things are getting faster" or "Things are getting slower." What this does is use an existing framework that can test speed for given things against differing values for dependencies (i.e., numpy version, h5py version, sympy version), changeset hashes in the main repository, and machine. And once the benchmarks are run, they get published and we can view them nicely. They even come up with things like interactive visualization of where time is spent.

So what I want to see is added onto Fido reports for passing tests, is fido information about impact on performance. This way we can keep track of it before things get accepted. And, the act of writing a benchmark is an awful lot like writing a test, so we may even be able to re-use some code. Since in the next little while I want to spend some time on performance, I thought this would be a nice way to make it systematic.

I'll start by porting the performance tests Sam Skillman and I worked on to it.

content.raw:
I initially suggested to keep this as part of *yt_analysis/yt*, but after giving it more thoughts I'd like to retract my suggestions. There are (at least) two reasons:

* results of benchmarks are text (json) files and can (should) be stored in the repository. I guess we wouldn't like to "pollute" main repo with that.
* asv can be used to host www results pages. It'll be much easier to just clone simple, lightweight repo and start www server from there.
content.html:
I initially suggested to keep this as part of yt_analysis/yt, but after giving it more thoughts I'd like to retract my suggestions. There are (at least) two reasons:

  • results of benchmarks are text (json) files and can (should) be stored in the repository. I guess we wouldn't like to "pollute" main repo with that.
  • asv can be used to host www results pages. It'll be much easier to just clone simple, lightweight repo and start www server from there.

content.raw: Alright, sounds good.  Should we use this PR to discuss a bit, then start a new repo once we're in agreement?  I'll then strip my changes out and decline the PR.
content.html: Alright, sounds good. Should we use this PR to discuss a bit, then start a new repo once we're in agreement? I'll then strip my changes out and decline the PR.

content.raw: I think it's worthwhile to keep benchmarks in the same repo as the code.  What do you think about having a separate yt-asv repo that copies benchmarks from a clone of yt_analysis/yt?  Is that doable?
content.html: I think it's worthwhile to keep benchmarks in the same repo as the code. What do you think about having a separate yt-asv repo that copies benchmarks from a clone of yt_analysis/yt? Is that doable?

content.raw: That might be the best solution.
So I think pending the YTEP acceptance, this is ready to go in.
content.html: So I think pending the YTEP acceptance, this is ready to go in.

content.raw: @xarthisius if you're okay, I'm okay with this.
content.html: Kacper Kowalik if you're okay, I'm okay with this.
